title: Mitigation Techniques
subtitle: Reducing Risk When Immediate Remediation Isn't Possible

introduction.hook: When the Log4Shell vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228) hit in December 2021, organizations faced an impossible choice: patch immediately (breaking production systems) or remain vulnerable to active exploitation. The answer wasn't either/or - it was mitigation. WAF rules blocked exploitation attempts while teams tested patches. Network segmentation limited blast radius. Egress filtering prevented callback connections. Organizations that had mitigation capabilities bought critical time; those without scrambled or got breached.
learning_goals: Distinguish between mitigation (temporary risk reduction) and remediation (permanent fix)
Apply network segmentation to contain threats and limit lateral movement
Implement compensating controls when direct fixes aren't possible
Use defense in depth to layer multiple mitigation techniques
Select appropriate mitigations based on threat type and business constraints

sections.title: Mitigation vs Remediation
sections.content:
Mitigation reduces risk temporarily; remediation eliminates the vulnerability permanently. When a critical vulnerability is discovered, immediate patching may not be possible - systems need testing, change windows must be scheduled, legacy systems may not have patches. Mitigation buys time by reducing exploitability or limiting impact without fully fixing the root cause. The goal is risk reduction to an acceptable level while permanent solutions are developed.

Understanding these concepts is critical for exam success and real-world application. Security professionals encounter these scenarios regularly, making mastery essential. The key aspects to remember include: Mitigation = temporary risk reduction (compensating control). Additionally, Remediation = permanent fix (patch, code fix, replacement) represents another crucial element. Organizations implementing these practices see measurable improvements in their security posture. Regular review and hands-on practice reinforce these concepts for long-term retention.
key_points: Mitigation = temporary risk reduction (compensating control)
Remediation = permanent fix (patch, code fix, replacement)
Mitigation buys time while remediation is prepared
Acceptable risk level determines mitigation adequacy
Both are needed - mitigate now, remediate soon

mnemonics.mnemonic: Mitigate = Manage temporarily, Remediate = Remove permanently
mnemonics.explanation: Mitigation reduces risk; remediation eliminates it

mnemonics.mnemonic: Can't patch? MITIGATE: Monitor, Isolate, Tighten, Inspect, Guard, Alert, Test, Evaluate
mnemonics.explanation: Actions when immediate remediation isn't possible

common_mistakes.mistake: Treating mitigation as a permanent solution
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Mitigations can be bypassed, may degrade over time, and don't fix the underlying vulnerability.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Mitigation is temporary. Always plan and execute remediation. Track mitigation expiration dates.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Mitigations are temporary - remediation is still required

common_mistakes.why_wrong: It's not either/or. Mitigate immediately to reduce risk, then remediate when possible.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Do both: mitigate now for immediate risk reduction, remediate later for permanent fix.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Best practice is mitigate immediately AND remediate as soon as possible

sections.title: Network Segmentation and Isolation
sections.content:
Network segmentation divides the network into isolated zones, limiting lateral movement when breaches occur. Instead of a flat network where compromising one system gives access to all, segmentation creates barriers attackers must cross. VLANs provide basic separation. Firewalls between segments enforce access rules. Microsegmentation provides granular, workload-level isolation. Zero trust extends this by requiring authentication for every access attempt, even within segments.

Understanding these concepts is critical for exam success and real-world application. Security professionals encounter these scenarios regularly, making mastery essential. The key aspects to remember include: Flat networks allow unlimited lateral movement after initial compromise. Additionally, Segmentation creates barriers between network zones represents another crucial element. Organizations implementing these practices see measurable improvements in their security posture. Regular review and hands-on practice reinforce these concepts for long-term retention.
key_points: Flat networks allow unlimited lateral movement after initial compromise
Segmentation creates barriers between network zones
VLANs provide basic Layer 2 separation
Firewalls between segments enforce access policies
Microsegmentation provides workload-level isolation
Segment by: sensitivity (PCI, HIPAA), function (servers, workstations), risk level

mnemonics.mnemonic: CLIP = Contain breaches, Limit movement, Isolate critical assets, Protect sensitive data

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Segmentation CONTAINS breaches, it doesn't PREVENT initial compromise. Attackers can still get in through allowed paths.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Segmentation limits blast radius and lateral movement. Prevention requires other controls.

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Modern environments need segmentation by data sensitivity, application tier, and trust level - not just physical location.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Segment by sensitivity (PCI), function (web/app/db), and trust level. Location is just one factor.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Effective segmentation considers data sensitivity and function

sections.title: Compensating Controls
sections.content:
Compensating controls provide equivalent protection when primary controls can't be implemented. If you can't patch a vulnerability, compensating controls reduce the risk to an acceptable level. Examples: WAF rules to block exploitation attempts, network ACLs to limit access, enhanced monitoring to detect attacks, endpoint protection to stop execution. The key is demonstrating that compensating controls provide equivalent or better protection than the missing primary control.

Understanding these concepts is critical for exam success and real-world application. Security professionals encounter these scenarios regularly, making mastery essential. The key aspects to remember include: Compensating controls = alternative protection when primary isn't possible. Additionally, Must provide equivalent or better protection represents another crucial element. Organizations implementing these practices see measurable improvements in their security posture. Regular review and hands-on practice reinforce these concepts for long-term retention.
key_points: Compensating controls = alternative protection when primary isn't possible
Must provide equivalent or better protection
Common compensating controls: WAF, IPS, ACLs, enhanced monitoring, EDR
PCI-DSS has specific compensating control requirements
Document: what control is missing, why, what compensates, how it's equivalent

mnemonics.mnemonic: WAFER = WAF, ACLs, Firewall rules, EDR, Restrictions
CREW = Control missing, Reason, Equivalent control, Why it works
mnemonics.explanation: What to document for compensating controls

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Compensating controls must provide EQUIVALENT protection. A weak control doesn't adequately reduce risk.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Compensating controls should match or exceed the protection of the primary control.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Compensating controls must be equivalent, not just present

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Undocumented compensating controls fail audits and may be removed by unknowing admins.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Document what's compensated, why, and how. Include in exception tracking.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Documentation is required for compensating controls

sections.title: Defense in Depth Mitigation
sections.content:
Defense in depth applies multiple overlapping mitigations so that failure of one doesn't mean total compromise. For a single vulnerability, layer mitigations: WAF blocks exploitation attempts at the perimeter, network segmentation limits what an attacker can reach, endpoint protection stops malware execution, monitoring detects suspicious activity. Each layer catches what others miss. The goal is making successful attacks require bypassing multiple controls.

Understanding these concepts is critical for exam success and real-world application. Security professionals encounter these scenarios regularly, making mastery essential. The key aspects to remember include: No single mitigation is perfect - layer multiple controls. Additionally, Each layer catches what others miss represents another crucial element. Organizations implementing these practices see measurable improvements in their security posture. Regular review and hands-on practice reinforce these concepts for long-term retention.
key_points: No single mitigation is perfect - layer multiple controls
Each layer catches what others miss
Layers: Perimeter (WAF/IPS), Network (segmentation), Host (EDR), Application (hardening), Data (encryption)
Assume each layer will fail - design for attacker progression
Monitor all layers to detect when controls are bypassed

mnemonics.mnemonic: PNHAD = Perimeter, Network, Host, Application, Data
mnemonics.explanation: Five layers of defense in depth

mnemonics.mnemonic: If one fails, others catch it

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Any single control can be bypassed. Attackers specifically research how to evade the defenses they encounter.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Layer multiple mitigations. If WAF is bypassed, segmentation limits access. If that fails, EDR detects execution.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Single controls can be bypassed - layers are essential

common_mistakes.mistake: Implementing redundant rather than diverse controls
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Two firewalls from the same vendor have the same weaknesses. Diversity in control types provides better coverage.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Use diverse control types: network + host + application. Same control twice isn't defense in depth.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Defense in depth requires diversity, not redundancy

knowledge_check.explanation: Attackers adapt to defenses. Multiple layers require multiple bypasses, increasing difficulty and detection chance.

key_takeaways: Mitigation reduces risk temporarily; remediation eliminates it permanently - do both
Network segmentation contains breaches and limits lateral movement
Compensating controls must provide equivalent protection and be documented
Defense in depth layers multiple controls so no single bypass is catastrophic
Assume every control will fail - design for attacker progression
exam_tips: Segmentation contains but doesn't prevent breaches
Compensating controls require documentation and equivalent protection
Defense in depth requires diverse controls, not redundant ones
WAF, IPS, segmentation, and EDR are common mitigation tools
